author: Mirage News
title: Cairns Veteran Honoured at Australian War Memorial | Mirage News
text: The Australian War Memorial in Canberra will be commemorating the service and sacrifice of Myola resident Ronald Richard Veivers at the Last Post Ceremony on Tuesday, 23 January 2024. "Private Veivers was born in Mareeba in 1921 and served in the army in New Guinea during the Second World War," said Duncan Beard of the Australian War Memorial said. "Ronald grew up in a large family in Myola, just outside Cairns. He worked as a stockman before enlisting in the Army in 1942, aged 21." "In January 1944 Private Veivers took part in the battle of Shaggy Ridge, which played an important part in the Japanese defeat on the Huon Peninsula, New Guinea. Ronald was killed during the assault and buried near where he fell, before being reburied at Lae War Cemetery, where his remains lie today." The Last Post ceremony is held at 4.30 pm every day except Christmas Day in the Commemorative area of the Australian War Memorial. Each ceremony shares the story behind one of 103,000 names on the [Roll of Honour](https://www.awm.gov.au/commemoration/honour-rolls/roll-of-honour). To date, the Memorial has delivered more than 3,300 ceremonies, each featuring an individual story of service from colonial times to recent conflicts. It would take more than 280 years to read the story behind each of the 103,000 names listed on the Roll of Honour. "The Last Post Ceremony is our commitment to remembering and honouring the legacy of Australian service," Memorial Director Matt Anderson said. "Through our daily Last Post Ceremony, we not only acknowledge where and how these men and women died. We also tell the stories of who they were when they were alive, and of the families who loved and, in so many cases, still mourn for them. "The Last Post is now associated with remembrance, but originally it was a bugle call to sound the end of the day's activities in the military. It is a fitting way to end each day at the Memorial." The Last Post Ceremony honouring the service of Private Ronald Veivers will be live-streamed to the Australian War Memorial's YouTube page; [https://www.youtube.com/c/awmlastpost](https://www.youtube.com/c/awmlastpost). The stories told at the Last Post Ceremony are researched and written by the Memorial's military historians, who begin the process by looking at nominal rolls, attestation papers and enlistment records before building profiles that include personal milestones and military experiences. [here](/cairns-veteran-honoured-at-australian-war-1158224/).

author: February ; Colleen Regan
title: Donâ€™t trash it, compost it: Mason Facilities adds 23 Bigbelly zero waste stations to campuses
text:
George Mason University Facilities has installed 23 Bigbelly zero waste stations on the Fairfax and Mason Square campuses. These solar-powered stations support Masonâ€™s recycling and composting goals through their user-friendly design, technology upgrades, and capacity-based alerts.
Five of the new Bigbelly stations on the Fairfax Campus include solar-powered, waste compacting compost bins at outdoor patio sites. Expanded composting access is part of a long-term strategy to improve Masonâ€™s waste diversion rateâ€”the amount of waste composted, recycled, repurposed, or otherwise diverted away from trash.
The Bigbelly zero waste stations expand the waste collection benefits achieved through Masonâ€™s
industrial composting pilot. Launched in August 2022, the composting pilot included the installation of Masonâ€™s first indoor zero waste station in the Starbucks located in Northern Neck on the Fairfax Campus. The project was funded by University Sustainability's Patriot Green Fund (PGF). A previous PGF grant supported the installation of Bigbellyâ€™s smart-waste management system at the patio outside the Starbucks.
Capacity alerts from Bigbelly solar zero waste stations increase the efficiency of operations for recycling and housekeeping staff, who are automatically alerted when the stations need to be emptied.
To successfully divert food scraps and other compostable items, the university must maintain a clean compost stream. Design changes were installed at waste stations to help reduce waste contamination. The Max-R zero waste station inside the on-campus Starbucks offers helpful design features like waste stream co-location, restrictive lid openings, and color-coded messaging. The station is made of more than 1,600 reclaimed milk jugs, supporting Masonâ€™s post-consumer recycled purchasing
goals and guidance.
The involvement of Mason Dining was crucial for the success of the industrial composting pilot. Mason Dining staff identified difficult-to-sort items, inventoried common contaminants during weekly audits, and piloted behavioral and educational interventions to support appropriate waste disposal.
Learn the best ways to sort your compost, recycling, and trash. Check out the
Zero Waste Mason page and see the complete list of zero waste locations.

author: @TUDNUSA
title: Grupo Firme: Integrante rompe exclusiva pieza de chocolate valuada en miles de pesos en tienda de lujo | Shows Famosos | Las Estrellas
text:
Integrante de Grupo Firme rompe exclusiva pieza de chocolate valuada en miles de pesos
Durante su visita a la tienda del influencer Juan Bertheau, uno de los integrantes de Grupo Firme rompiÃ³, por accidente, un bolso de chocolate de una marca de lujo, el cual estÃ¡ valuado en miles de pesos y solo existÃ­an 8 piezas en el mundo.
Eduin Caz denunciÃ³ este 11 de mayo que sufriÃ³ un robotras un concierto con Grupo Firme en San Antonio, Texas. Con Ã©l estaba su madre y una tÃ­a y da a conocer cÃ³mo se encuentran tras los hechos. Es el segundo hurto que el cantante sufre en casi 8 meses.
Â¡Espera! Antes de que sigas,
te invitamos a ver ViX: entretenimiento sin lÃ­mites con mÃ¡s de 100 canales, totalmente gratis y en espaÃ±ol. Disfruta de cine, series, telenovelas, deportes y miles de horas de contenido en tu idioma.
Un integrante de Grupo Firme rompiÃ³ accidentalmente una pieza de chocolate de ediciÃ³n limitada considerada la mÃ¡s costosa de MÃ©xico, durante una visita a una tienda ubicada en la zona de Polanco, en la Ciudad de MÃ©xico.
Integrante de Grupo Firme rompe pieza de chocolate de ediciÃ³n limitada en tienda de lujo
El incidente ocurriÃ³ mientras los integrantes de Grupo Firme participaban en la grabaciÃ³n de un video junto al influencer Juan Bertheau, el cual se volviÃ³ viral tras su lanzamiento el pasado 14 de julio en su canal de Youtube.
En el video, el influencer les presenta una pieza exclusiva de la marca de lujo Louis Vuitton: Un bolso hecho de chocolate, el cual costÃ³ 245 dÃ³lares (4 mil 595 pesos) y, debido a que solo existÃ­an 8 piezas en todo el mundo, su precio ascendiÃ³ a 25 mil pesos, ya que la tienda solo lo ofrecÃ­a a compradores muy exclusivos.
Mientras Eduin Caz continuÃ³ conversando con Bertheau, se muestra el momento en que Abraham, uno de los integrantes del grupo, toma el chocolate y lo rompe.
"Â¡No ma#$%, Abraham! Â¿CuÃ¡nto vale el huevo? Para saber cuÃ¡nto le muerdo. HabÃ­a ocho en todo el mundo, ya solo habrÃ¡ siete, porque nos comeremos uno", dijo, entre risas.

Marca de lujo lanza costoso bolso hecho de chocolate
El producto forma parte de una colaboraciÃ³n entre Louis Vuitton y Maxime FrÃ©dÃ©ric, Chef Pastelero del AÃ±o segÃºn la GuÃ­a Gault & Millau 2022 y Chef Pastelero de Cheval Blanc Paris. Su diseÃ±o y elaboraciÃ³n lo posicionan como un artÃ­culo de lujo dentro del mercado gourmet.
â€œMaxime FrÃ©dÃ©ric desvela una nueva colecciÃ³n de bombones de Pascua. Este aÃ±o, la 'Bolsa de huevos de chocolate', inspirada en el icÃ³nico modelo creado por Nicolas GhesquiÃ¨re, Director ArtÃ­stico de las colecciones femeninas, se transforma en chocolateâ€, dice el sitio web.
Los chocolates solo pueden ser adquiridos en las tiendas de ParÃ­s, Singapur y Shanghai, lo cual lo hace aÃºn mÃ¡s exclusivo, y fue gracias a las redes sociales que se revelÃ³ que tenÃ­a un costo inicial de 245 dÃ³lares.

author: Joanna Brown
title: New Illinois law should help survivors of gender violence who sue their employers â€“ WBEZ (Chicago)
text: New Illinois law should help survivors of gender violence who sue their employers The law, which takes effect Jan. 1, is intended to hold employers accountable for failing to act on complaints of workplace violence.By [Dan Mihalopoulos](/staff/211/dan-mihalopoulos) New Illinois law should help survivors of gender violence who sue their employers The law, which takes effect Jan. 1, is intended to hold employers accountable for failing to act on complaints of workplace violence.By [Dan Mihalopoulos](/staff/211/dan-mihalopoulos) [Sign up for our newsletters](/newsletters)to stay up to date on the stories that matter. A new Illinois law that will go into effect on Jan. 1 should make it easier for survivors of gender violence to sue their employers successfully, say the measureâ€™s sponsors and plaintiffsâ€™ lawyers who pushed for the changes to the statutes in Springfield. The law will allow workers to hold their employer liable for failing â€œto supervise, train, or monitor the employee who engaged in the gender-related violenceâ€ or for not taking â€œremedial measuresâ€ after being informed of alleged misconduct in the workplace. State Rep. Will Guzzardi, D-Chicago, introduced the legislation in the Illinois House. He said the new law should help survivors who face sexual violence on the job in cases where there were systemic problems that the employers tolerated. â€œOur message to the survivors is that weâ€™re going to hold accountable not just the perpetrators of the violence, but those people and institutions that should have intervened and didnâ€™t,â€ Guzzardi told WBEZ recently. â€œThe bosses, the employers who knew or who should have known this kind of violence was happening and turned a blind eye â€” they too will be held accountable. This legislation will help survivors to seek real remedy for that kind of harm.â€ [ Two former lifeguards sue the Chicago Park District, saying they suffered sexual abuse when they were minors ](/stories/two-former-lifeguards-sue-the-chicago-park-district-saying-they-suffered-sexual-abuse-when-they-were-minors/31148d25-6a80-405e-b419-2ebddeadf21e) The measure was approved in the spring legislative session by the Illinois House and Senate and signed by Gov. JB Pritzker in July. â€œWhen I hear that folks are going to their employer and telling them about harassment that happens in the workplace, and the employers are not taking that seriously, then I really think that there needs to be recourse for these victims,â€ said the Senate sponsor of the new law, Karina Villa, D-West Chicago. Among those who lobbied lawmakers to pass the measure was attorney Bridget Duignan. Her clients include female ex-lifeguards who have received settlements from the Chicago Park District or [are suing the agency currently](/stories/two-former-lifeguards-sue-the-chicago-park-district-saying-they-suffered-sexual-abuse-when-they-were-minors/31148d25-6a80-405e-b419-2ebddeadf21e), alleging widespread sexual misconduct by supervisors at the [cityâ€™s public beaches and pools](/stories/female-ex-lifeguards-describe-deacdes-of-sexual-abuse-at-chicagos-beaches-and-pools/a1844d7a-bedd-43be-89b0-040d8c7f72cc). Although the park district board has agreed to pay settlements totaling nearly $2 million to three women, Duignan said officials had attempted to dodge liability by arguing that the stateâ€™s Gender Violence Act, which was approved in 2003, did not apply to employers. Duignan and the legislative sponsors said they hoped the new law would eliminate any doubt that employers can be held liable. It also could make it much easier for survivors to get financial compensation. â€œIf youâ€™re going to recover damages, itâ€™s more likely than not impossible to recover the types of damages that you suffered from an individual, versus an employer who has the means to pay a damage award,â€ Duignan said. The proposal passed by a 50-0 vote in the state Senate and by a 73-35 margin in the Illinois House in May. According to a transcript of the House debate, the only lawmaker who spoke against the measure was Rep. Dan Ugaste, R-Geneva, who said the changes would â€œbring down our economy even further.â€ â€œAll itâ€™s doing is adding more fuel for the various groups to try and make money off of litigation in this state,â€ Ugaste said. â€œAnd itâ€™s going to hamper business and going to have to keep them from hiring more people, investing in their businesses and expanding the Illinois economy.â€ Ugaste argued that there already are laws that allow employees to â€œstill collect from the employer if thereâ€™s something in fact that the employer did to contribute to this.â€ But plaintiffsâ€™ lawyers said the courts in different cases had shown that greater clarity was needed. â€œThere was a lot of confusion among employees and employers as to what circumstances, if any, could lead to liability for gender violence,â€ said employment lawyer Gail Schnitzer Eisenberg. She said the new law would succeed in â€œreally specifying what those circumstances for employer liability could be.â€ The Gender Violence Act gives an accuser seven years to file claims against individuals. But under the new law, the statute of limitations for suing an employer would be four years â€” though minors who are harmed at work would have four years after they turn 18 to bring a claim. Dan Mihalopoulos is an investigative reporter on WBEZâ€™s Government & Politics Team.

author: @pajaronian
title: Rain, cold move in
text:
Cold rain showers managed to slip in the door before October wrapped up, with temperatures dropping and a dowsing shower early Thursday morning.
Meteorologist Dial Hoang of the National Weather Service of Monterey said the colder, wet system moved into the region from the Pacific Northwest and will be followed by another similar system, arriving later today.
â€œThis low pressure system will move in Friday evening and extend into Saturday in the Watsonville area and give us another shot of rain,â€ Hoang said. â€œTodayâ€™s high will be around the mid-60s and tonightâ€™s low will be around 43 degrees.â€
Starting Sunday a â€œwarming and drying trendâ€ will seep into our area and continue at least into mid-week with daily highs in the mid-70s.
â€œThat should continue through Thursday,â€ Hoang said. â€œThe rains this week â€” Friday and Saturday â€” could bring a rainfall total of a half-inch in the lower regions and around three-quarters of an inch in the mountains.â€
Meanwhile, on a longer range, meteorologist Dalton Behringer said that looking forward through January â€œthere are no strong signals for el niÃ±o or el niÃ±a weather patterns â€”heavy rain and drier conditionsâ€” predicted yet for the Central Coast. â€œOf course, this depends on many factors. But right now, it appears November into January looks to be edging toward a 33% chance of above average temperatures.â€ He added that, at this point, precipitation appears to be sitting on the fence, meaning there are no strong indicators that rain will be heavy or light.
â€œThat outlook, of course, can always change.â€

author: LMNeuquen
title: Bombazo: tras el rechazo de Boca, Palermo revelÃ³ que podrÃ­a ser DT de River
text:
En la previa a las elecciones presidenciales que se desarrollaron en Boca cada candidato tenÃ­a su posible entrenador en caso de ser elegido. En el caso de AndrÃ©s Ibarra el posible DT iba a ser MartÃ­n Palermo, quien se mostrÃ³ afÃ­n a esa lÃ­nea polÃ­tica. Tras conocerse la historia, se supo que la llegada del TitÃ¡n serÃ­a imposible.
El ex goleador del Xeneize participÃ³ de un partido benÃ©fico en Brasil y tras eso aprovechpÃ³ y respondiÃ³ algunas preguntas de la prensa local en la que se refiriÃ³ a su futuro.
La bomba de MartÃ­n Palermo sobre su futuro dlgFZw5H-34516613.mp4 El entrenador decidiÃ³ no renovar su vÃ­nculo con Platense despuÃ©s de haber jugador la final de la Copa de la Liga, que perdiÃ³ 1-0 frente a Rosario Central, y ahora su prÃ³ximo destino es incierto. En este contexto, se le consultÃ³ sobre quÃ© propuestas podrÃ­a aceptar.
Una de las consultas era si aceptarÃ­a dirigir a algÃºn equipo que fuese clÃ¡sico del Xeneize, como River Plate, Independiente o Racing: â€œObviamente, mi trabajo es dirigir el equipo que me proponga ser el entrenador que tenga un proyecto. Estoy preparado para dirigir cualquier equipoâ€.
Esta frase disparÃ³ la discusiÃ³n en redes sociales, sobre todo por aquellos boquenses que lo idolatran y que esperaban tal vez otra respuesta del TitÃ¡n. Es importante destacar que en la actualidad el Millonario no tiene en carpeta al ex delantero, y tampoco es opciÃ³n en Racing e Independiente, que estÃ¡n bajo las direcciones tÃ©cnicas de Gustavo Costas y Carlos Tevez, respectivamente. Por eso, Palermo aguarda tambiÃ©n por alguna oferta del exterior, ya sea Chile, MÃ©xico o incluso Brasil.
Pese a la gran rivalidad que existe entre los dos clubes mÃ¡s poderosos de la Argentina, han habido algunos tÃ©cnicos que se han puesto el buzo de uno de esos equipos, pese a haber estado identificados con el otro.
Por ejemplo, Juan JosÃ© LÃ³pez, quien fuera futbolista de ambos conjuntos y ademÃ¡s dirigiÃ³ a River Plate en 2011, o CÃ©sar Luis Menotti, quien tuvo un paso como jugador de Boca Juniors y fue entrenador de ambos clubes. HÃ©ctor Bambino Veira tambiÃ©n es un caso a destacar porque supo dirigir a ambos.

author: CBCP News
title: Bishops join protest against Charter change
text: Some Catholic bishops accompanied protesters in Manila against the current attempts to tweak the Constitution. Bishop Jose Colin Bagaforo of Caritas Philippines said they are not letting their guards down against what he called â€˜underground worksâ€™ for Charter change through the supposed â€œpeopleâ€™s initiativeâ€. â€œWe are still concerned because we are not sure of the strength of the underground works and they might give value to what is called â€˜fakeâ€™ peopleâ€™s initiative,â€ Bagaforo told reporters. â€œSo we need to be critical, we need to stand up, and we need to raise the voice of the majority,â€ he said. Bagaforo was joined by Bishop Emeritus Deogracias IÃ±iguez of Kalookan and former chairman of the CBCPâ€™s Episcopal Commission on Public Affairs. Several priests and nuns were also seen at the rally held at Plaza Roma, right in front of the Palacio del Gobernador where the main office of the Commission on Elections is located. The demonstration was organized by â€œKoalisyon Laban sa ChaChaâ€, composed of various religious groups and civil society organizations. Bagaforo, who is also the bishop of Kidapawan, called on the faithful not to allow lawmakers to revise the Constitution without proper consultation and full transparency. â€œThere are many doubts because there is no transparency. What are their true intentions?â€ the prelate added. â€œWe pray that our leaders will not be led into the temptation of changing the Constitution for power and riches but instead be steadfast in fulfilling their duties and responsibilities as servant-leaders of the people,â€ he also said.

author: philomathnews.com - Julia Shumway, Oregon Capital Chronicle
title: Oregon Caves chateau named one of nation's most endangered historic places - Philomath News | Flipboard
text:
Oregon Caves chateau named one of nationâ€™s most endangered historic places - Philomath News The Depression-era chateau at the Oregon Caves National Monument and Preserve, closed since 2018 for rehabilitation work, is one of the nationâ€™s most â€¦
philomathnews.com - Julia Shumway, Oregon Capital Chronicle â€¢ 2h
